Award.AwardTitle: SusChEM: Continuous Flow Lignin Deconstruction in Supercritical Solvent Mixtures and Conversion to Renewable Chemicals

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Lignocellulosic biomass from agricultural waste and non-edible plants represents an abundant, inexpensive, and renewable source of carbon for the production of bio-based fuels, chemicals, and polymers. To be truly sustainable, new conversion processes that favor the use of green solvents, non-precious metal catalysts, and offer optimal biomass utilization need to be explored. The research objective of this project is to investigate the deconstruction of lignin, an underutilized biopolymer which accounts for up to 30% of lignocellulosic biomass, and its conversion to high value-added bio-based phenolic precursors for the industrial production of drugs, cosmetics, flavoring agents, and epoxy resins. The process combines the depolymerization of lignin in supercritical solvents and the catalytic upgrading of the resulting fragments to desired bio-based products.

The project will explore new processes to convert lignin, an industrial waste product that is currently burnt as low value boiler fuel, to high value-added chemicals of industrial significance. Specifically, the deconstruction and fractionation of industrial lignin in flow reactors using supercritical solvent mixtures will be studied in order to understand the involved mechanisms and identify conditions that favor high selectivity, thus benefiting the economics of the conversion process and the environment by reducing waste. High value building blocks such as p-coumaric acid and ferulic acid will be recovered while fractions with lower value monomers and oligomers will be further converted over nanostructured catalysts to bio-based phenolic platform chemicals. The outreach program primarily targets grades 7-12 high school teachers with the objective of generating excitement and interest in pursuing careers in STEM fields among their students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project focused on the valorization of lignin, a waste product from agriculture and from the paper and pulp industry, to valuable aromatic hydrocarbons, which are key building blocks in the chemical industry. Both lignin depolymerization and catalytic upgrading were investigated in this project. Lignin conversion in supercritical solvents using a flow-through reactor was developed to enable lignin depolymerization and its reactive fractionation simultaneously. In comparison to conventional lignin depolymerization in batch reactors, the flow-through reactor-approach was able to not only achieve higher total phenolic monomer yields, but also produce partly depolymerized lignin streams with high monomer and small oligomer concentrations. By converting lignin in a flow-through reactor, heat and mass transfer limitations were greatly diminished and recombination reactions of lignin-derived monomers could be inhibited to a great extent. The flow-through reactor approach is also considered an effective lignin pretreatment method. The pretreated lignin fractions were catalytically upgraded to produce significantly higher yields of aromatic monomers in comparison to traditional catalytic upgrading of lignin. The mechanisms of lignin depolymerization and catalytic upgrading were investigated in great details, also by employing lignin originated from different biomass sources and extraction methods, and using various solid catalysts. By elucidating the underlying mechanisms of lignin depolymerization and catalytic conversions, the findings derived from this research project will lead to an improved understanding of the lignin chemistry, which is essential to develop effective and economic pathways to valorize lignin to sustainable chemicals and fuels. In addition to advancing the valorization of waste lignin, this project served as a platform to train 2 graduate students and 2 undergraduates.
